title: Add system tray icon for background app control
description:
Implement system tray icon for console-free executable to provide user control and visibility.

REQUIREMENTS:

1. System Tray Icon:
   - Appears in Windows system tray when app runs
   - Uses app icon (assets/icon.ico)
   - Shows on hover: 'Burndown Chart - Running on http://127.0.0.1:8050'

2. Context Menu Actions:
   - 'Open in Browser' - Opens/focuses http://127.0.0.1:8050 in default browser
   - 'Quit' - Gracefully shuts down app (sys.exit(0))

3. Implementation Details:
   - Library: pystray (https://pypi.org/project/pystray/)
   - Add to requirements.in: pystray>=0.19.5
   - Tray icon runs in separate daemon thread
   - Must not block Dash/Waitress server
   - Icon file: assets/icon.ico (already exists for executable)

4. Files to Modify:
   - requirements.in - add pystray dependency
   - app.py - initialize tray icon when running as frozen executable
   - build/app.spec - ensure icon.ico is bundled (already is)

5. Code Structure:
   `python
   if getattr(sys, 'frozen', False):  # Only for executable
       import pystray
       from PIL import Image
       
       def on_open(icon, item):
           webbrowser.open('http://127.0.0.1:8050')
       
       def on_quit(icon, item):
           icon.stop()
           sys.exit(0)
       
       icon = pystray.Icon('burndown-chart',
           Image.open('assets/icon.ico'),
           'Burndown Chart',
           menu=pystray.Menu(
               pystray.MenuItem('Open in Browser', on_open),
               pystray.MenuItem('Quit', on_quit)
           ))
       
       # Run in separate thread
       threading.Thread(target=icon.run, daemon=True).start()
   `

6. Testing Checklist:
   - [ ] Tray icon appears when app starts
   - [ ] Hover shows app name and URL
   - [ ] 'Open in Browser' launches/focuses browser tab
   - [ ] 'Quit' cleanly shuts down app
   - [ ] Icon disappears when app exits
   - [ ] No tray icon when running 'python app.py' (source mode)
   - [ ] Works with update flow (old icon stops, new icon appears)

BENEFITS:
- User can always reopen browser if tab closed
- Clean way to quit without Task Manager
- Visibility that app is running
- Professional UX like mailhog, Docker Desktop, etc.

DEPENDENCIES:
- pystray: System tray icon library
- PIL/Pillow: Image handling (already installed via other deps)

BLOCKED BY:
- burndown-chart-rk4 (update UX improvements must be tested first)

title: Update mechanism UX improvements: speed, cleanup, silent operation
description:
Comprehensive improvements to the update flow beyond initial implementation:

COMPLETED IMPROVEMENTS:

1. App Exit Fix (CRITICAL):
   - Changed from graceful shutdown (blocking) to os._exit(0)
   - Allows updater to immediately replace executable files
   - File: data/update_manager.py

2. Speed Optimizations:
   - Added psutil for faster process detection (0.1s vs 0.5s polling)
   - Reduced updater delays: 1s → 0s after process exit, 3s → 1s final window
   - Faster tasklist polling fallback (0.2s vs 0.5s)
   - Total improvement: ~2-3 seconds faster update
   - Files: updater/updater.py, requirements.in

3. Cleanup Improvements:
   - Remove .bak file after successful update
   - Remove update ZIP file
   - Clean up temp directories (burndown_updater, burndown_updates)
   - File: updater/updater.py

4. Background Download with Progress:
   - Download runs in background thread (non-blocking UI)
   - Live progress bar updates via polling (0% → 100%)
   - Completion toast when download finishes
   - Files: callbacks/app_update.py, ui/layout.py

5. Footer Fallback Button:
   - Footer button works at all update stages
   - Triggers download when AVAILABLE, install when READY
   - Prevents need to restart app if toast dismissed
   - Files: callbacks/app_update.py, ui/layout.py

6. Silent Operation (Console-Free):
   - Changed app.spec: console=True → console=False
   - Changed updater.spec: console=True → console=False
   - No terminal windows at any stage
   - Clean background service like mailhog
   - All logs still in logs/app.log and logs/errors.log
   - Files: build/app.spec, build/updater.spec

7. User Guidance:
   - Toast message tells user to close browser tab
   - Clear instructions that new tab will open automatically
   - 30-second toast duration covers entire update process
   - File: callbacks/app_update.py

8. Browser Handling:
   - Changed webbrowser.open() to open(url, new=2, autoraise=True)
   - Attempts to reuse window (browser-dependent)
   - Auto-launches browser when no browser open
   - File: app.py

FILES MODIFIED:
- data/update_manager.py (exit fix)
- updater/updater.py (speed, cleanup, psutil)
- callbacks/app_update.py (background download, progress, toast)
- ui/layout.py (footer button, progress polling)
- build/app.spec (console=False)
- build/updater.spec (console=False)
- requirements.in (psutil)
- app.py (browser handling)

READY FOR TESTING:
Rebuild with: .\build\build.ps1 -VerboseBuild
Test complete update cycle with silent operation

RELATED TASKS:
- Completes T054 (graceful shutdown delay)
- Improves T053 (user guidance for disconnection)

title: Review and improve about dialog tab structure
description: Evaluate whether having latest release in App Info tab AND full changelog in separate tab is redundant. Research common practices for about dialogs. Consider: (1) Keep current structure, (2) Remove duplication - only show version info in App Info, (3) Merge into single scrollable view. Decide on best UX and implement.
notes: Current structure: App Info (version + latest 5 items), Open Source (core tech attributions), Licenses (full list), Changelog (full history). Research shows this is GOOD UX practice - 'What's New' preview in App Info with link to full changelog is common (VS Code, Slack, GitHub Desktop do this). Users want quick info without scrolling. DECISION: Keep current structure - it follows best practices and provides good progressive disclosure.
